Scrambled eggs are both the easiest and the hardest version of eggs to make. There may not be any expert flipping or swirling involved, but one misstep and you could up with something bouncy and rubbery. To avoid that, you’ll want to keep the heat closer to low when attempting this style. It is recommended to stir them constantly over low-heat with a tablespoon of butter.
You can also totally just toss your eggs directly into a hot pan and scramble them right there. If you do choose this method, make sure the pan doesn’t get too hot, and be attentive. It shouldn’t take you more than a minute or two.

It’s important to flash the eggs in cold water after cooking them, because, that’s what prevents the eggs from getting grey.
One excellent trick to keep in mind when boiling eggs is that the older they are, the easier it is to peel them.

You can add a fried egg to almost anything with guaranteed deliciousness. It’s an excellent way to sneak a little extra protein into anything from avocado toast to mixed greens to vegetable stir-frys. When you’re ready to get frying, it’s important to remember one thing: don’t ever let the pan get too hot. That’s when the egg starts to brown. Eggs are the one protein on earth that don’t taste better when they’re brown.

All you need is a microwave and a mug and you’ve got a poached egg. Crack the egg into a mug and add a half cup of water so you don’t scramble it. Then cover the mug with a paper towel, and cook for one minute. Drain off the water, holding the egg back with a fork.

If you choose to fill it up, make sure whatever you’re using gets a quick sauté before you add the eggs—you don’t want an omelet filled with raw veggies. From there, you can either dump the eggs directly onto the pan with the filling, or set the veggies aside and add them to the eggs later on, so that it’s more like a wrap.
On the other hand, when it comes to a classic, filling-free omelet it’s all about the shaking and scrambling. This method will give you a really tender sheet of eggs, perfect for enjoying all on it’s own.
